L1.brief_rationale: The most iconic concept in calculus; universally taught as the instantaneous rate of change and slope of a tangent line.
The other pillar of calculus; widely recognized as computing areas under curves and accumulations.
Foundational concept underlying all of calculus; taught in every introductory calculus course as the first major topic.
Intuitive concept of an unbroken curve; universally recognized from introductory calculus and pre-calculus.
Widely recognized as equations involving derivatives; familiar from science and engineering education.
Geometric interpretation of the derivative; universally taught and visualizable from basic calculus.
Primary geometric motivation for integration; universally presented as the central application of definite integrals.
Pre-calculus concept that generalizes to the derivative; universally known from algebra and geometry.
Point where a curve changes concavity; widely taught in introductory calculus as a key concept in curve sketching.
Line a curve approaches but never reaches; widely taught in pre-calculus and calculus courses.
Whether a curve bends upward or downward; universally taught in introductory calculus for curve analysis.
The reverse operation of differentiation; universally introduced alongside integration in first-semester calculus.
The central theorem linking differentiation and integration; taught in every introductory calculus course as its capstone result.

L2.brief_rationale: Specific differentiation rule for composite functions; named result universally memorized in first-semester calculus.
Specific differentiation rule for products of functions; named result taught in every introductory calculus course.
Specific technique of approximating integrals with rectangles; named result central to the definition of the definite integral.
Named rule for evaluating indeterminate limits using derivatives; specific technique taught in first-year calculus.
Specific integration technique derived from the product rule; named method universally taught in second-semester calculus.
Named power series expansion of a function around a point; specific result taught in second-semester calculus as a major topic.
Derivative with respect to one variable while holding others fixed; specific technical concept from multivariable calculus.
Vector of partial derivatives pointing in the direction of steepest ascent; specific named concept from multivariable calculus.
Technique for differentiating relations not solved for one variable; specific method taught in first-semester calculus.
Taylor series centered at zero; specific named case universally presented as the standard power series examples (e^x, sin x, cos x).
Formal definition of a limit using epsilon and delta; specific technical definition that distinguishes rigorous calculus from intuitive approaches.
Named theorem guaranteeing a point where instantaneous rate equals average rate; specific major result in differential calculus.
Technique for integration using a change of variable; specific named method (also called u-substitution) universally taught in calculus.

L3.brief_rationale: Relates volume integral of divergence to surface flux integral; requires working knowledge of vector calculus and how it extends the FTC.
Relates surface integral of curl to line integral around boundary; requires working knowledge of differential forms and vector calculus.
Relates line integral around closed curve to double integral over enclosed region; requires working knowledge of planar vector calculus.
Technique for constrained optimization using auxiliary variables; requires working knowledge of multivariable calculus and the geometry of level curves.
Integrals over unbounded domains or with singularities evaluated as limits; requires working knowledge of convergence and limit concepts.
Theorem bounding the error of Taylor polynomial approximations via the remainder term; requires working understanding of how series approximate functions.
Matrix of all partial derivatives of a vector-valued function; requires working knowledge of multivariable differentiation and change-of-variables in integration.
Suite of tests (ratio, root, comparison, integral) for determining series convergence; requires working knowledge of infinite series behavior.
Integration of a function along a curve in space; requires working knowledge of parameterization and vector fields.
ODEs solvable by separating variables onto opposite sides; requires working knowledge of integration techniques and ODE solution methods.
Infinite series of the form sum of a_n(x-c)^n with radius of convergence; requires working knowledge of series convergence and function representation.
Integral formula for the length of a curve; requires working knowledge of the derivation from Pythagorean theorem and its multivariable extensions.

L4.brief_rationale: Measure-theoretic generalization of the Riemann integral integrating over measurable sets; requires deep knowledge of real analysis and measure theory.
Unification of FTC, Green's, Stokes', and divergence theorems via differential forms on manifolds; requires deep knowledge of differential geometry.
Generalization of the derivative to maps between Banach spaces; requires deep knowledge of functional analysis and infinite-dimensional calculus.
Optimization over function spaces using functionals and the Euler-Lagrange equation; requires deep knowledge linking calculus to physics and optimization theory.
Necessary condition for extremizing a functional; requires deep knowledge of variational calculus and its applications in mechanics and geometry.
Representation of periodic functions as sums of sines and cosines; requires deep knowledge of orthogonality, convergence, and function spaces.
Conditions for complex differentiability defining holomorphic functions; requires deep knowledge bridging real multivariable calculus and complex analysis.
Topology of manifolds via critical points of smooth functions; requires deep knowledge connecting differential calculus to algebraic topology.
Almost all values of a smooth map are regular values; requires deep knowledge of measure theory and smooth manifold theory.
Generalization of gradient, curl, and divergence to differential forms; requires deep knowledge of differential geometry and the wedge product formalism.
Integral inequality bounding solutions to differential inequalities; requires deep knowledge of ODEs and its use in proving existence, uniqueness, and stability results.
Stronger form of convergence that preserves continuity and allows interchange of limits with integrals and derivatives; requires deep knowledge of real analysis foundations.
